TITLE I--HEALTH CARE FRAUD PROSECUTION

SEC. 101. SHORT TITLE.

This title may be cited as the "Health Care Fraud Prosecution Act of 1995".

SEC. 102. INCREASED PENALTIES FOR HEALTH CARE FRAUD. The Health Care Fraud Prosecution Act of 1995 introduces new penalties for health care fraud under Chapter 50B, including definitions of health care providers and offenses related to fraudulent conduct in connection with health care provision. The Health Care Fraud Prosecution Act of 1995 establishes penalties for health care fraud, including fines and imprisonment for fraudulent conduct exceeding $10,000 or for offenders with prior fraud convictions. Offenders can be sentenced to up to 10 years in prison for serious physical injury or endangerment of a patient. The Health Care Fraud Prosecution Act of 1995 establishes penalties for health care fraud, including fines and imprisonment for fraudulent conduct exceeding $10,000 or for offenders with prior fraud convictions. Offenders can be sentenced to up to 10 years in prison for serious physical injury or endangerment of a patient. In cases where the offense causes the death of a patient, the offender may face a maximum sentence of life imprisonment. Restitution must be paid to the patient and any payor for economic losses resulting from the offense. (b) Clerical Amendment.--The table of chapters in part I of title 18, United States Code, is updated to include a new item after chapter 50A. SEC. 103 amends Section 982(a) of title 18, United States Code, to include criminal forfeiture of health care fraud proceeds. SEC. 104 amends Section 3059(c)(1) to provide rewards for information leading to prosecution and conviction. SEC. 105 authorizes appropriations. Authorized appropriations for fiscal year 1996 include $25 million for the FBI to hire agents to investigate health-care fraud, $5 million for prosecutors, and $5 million for investigators in the Office of Inspector General. Additional funding will be provided as needed in subsequent fiscal years. TITLE II--HEALTH CARE FRAUD AND ABUSE COMMISSION

Establishment of Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission under the Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission Act of 1995. The Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission, established under the Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission Act of 1995, consists of 18 members including government officials and public appointees. The Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission, established in 1995, consists of 13 public members appointed by the President, including representatives from various sectors such as State Medicaid fraud control programs, health insurance regulation, physicians, hospital administrators, health insurance companies, and employers. The Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission, established in 1995, consists of 13 public members appointed by the President, including representatives from various sectors such as State Medicaid fraud control programs, health insurance regulation, physicians, hospital administrators, health insurance companies, employers, medicare carriers, medicare peer review organizations, health care consumers, medicare beneficiaries, and labor unions. The President considers recommendations from national organizations when appointing representatives. The President must report the members' names to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Each member of the Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission is appointed for life, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 203. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with investigating health care fraud and abuse in the US, developing effective prevention and detection methods, and coordinating public and private efforts. It will also examine mechanisms for standardizing claims administration and allowing health benefit plans to exchange information for fraud prevention without compromising privacy protections. The curr_chunk discusses various measures to combat health care fraud and abuse, including extending administrative remedies to private insurers, organizing investigation efforts, creating state insurance fraud units, regulating new healthcare providers, setting criteria for physician referrals, and providing resources to law enforcement. The Commission will report to Congress on its activities within 18 months of appointing public members, including findings and recommendations on combating health care fraud and abuse. SEC. 204. ORGANIZATION AND COMPENSATION. The Commission shall have a majority quorum for hearings, elect a chairman from its members, and hold meetings as called by the chairman or majority. Meetings are open to the public, but can be in executive session with majority approval. Members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for expenses. Members of the Commission are reimbursed for expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. SEC. 205. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission may appoint staff and additional personnel without following standard appointment and compensation rules. Federal employees can be detailed to assist the Commission without losing their civil service status. The Commission can also hire experts and consultants at specific rates. The Commission has the authority to appoint staff and personnel without standard rules, hire experts and consultants at specific rates, and pay up to 120% of the maximum annual rate for GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, obtain official data from government agencies, and make information available to the public in accordance with relevant laws. The Commission, under title 5 of the United States Code, can accept gifts, use the United States mails, receive administrative support services, and issue subpoenas for witness testimony and evidence. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witness testimony and evidence related to investigations. Failure to comply with a subpoena may result in a court order for testimony or evidence, with non-compliance punishable as civil contempt. The court may punish non-compliance with subpoenas as civil contempt. Subpoenas are served as per Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Process serving can be done in the person's judicial district. SEC. 207 states that the Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report under section 203(c). SEC. 208 authorizes appropriations necessary for the Commission's functions.
